content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are given a cylindrical resistor and asked to determine if the resistor is ohmic.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to use a graph to determine whether the resistor is ohmic. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are given a cylindrical resistor and asked to determine if the resistor is ohmic.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to use a graph to determine whether the resistor is ohmic. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe how the data could be analyzed to determine whether the resistor is ohmic.

The students are given several cylindrical resistors that are made from the same material and are known to be ohmic. The students are asked to determine the resistivity <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> of the material that the resistors are made from. The resistors have various cross-sectional areas <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math> and lengths <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, as shown. They connect each resistor, one at a time, to a circuit in which an ammeter measures the current in the resistor and a variable power supply is set so that the potential difference across the cylinder is <math alttext="5.0 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></math>. The students’ data are listed in the table.
<math alttext="area in meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="length in meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>(m)</mtext></math><math alttext="I in milliamps" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>(mA)</mtext></math><math alttext="1.20 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.20</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math><math alttext="0.020" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.020</mn></math><math alttext="4.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.5</mn></math><math alttext="1.20 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.20</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math><math alttext="0.040" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.040</mn></math><math alttext="2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.5</mn></math><math alttext="4.40 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.40</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math><math alttext="0.040" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.040</mn></math><math alttext="8.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.0</mn></math><math alttext="4.40 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.40</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math><math alttext="0.060" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.060</mn></math><math alttext="5.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.3</mn></math><math alttext="9.60 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9.60</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math><math alttext="0.060" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.060</mn></math><math alttext="12.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>12.5</mn></math>

(c)

i. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to produce a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value of the resistivity <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.

Horizontal axis: __________          Vertical axis: __________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the grid provided. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw a best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).

(d) Using the best-fit line and the potential difference of <math alttext="5.0 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></math>, calculate an experimental value of the resistivity <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
